<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 220, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 259]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 722, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 256]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 361, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2022 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 285, 450]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|> Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|> Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|> Write your answer to each question in the space provided. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|> Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|> Do not write on any bar codes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 798, 544]]<|/det|> You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 892, 575]]<|/det|> You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 320, 590]]<|/det|> You may use a calculator. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 590, 578, 605]]<|/det|> You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 220, 649]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 384, 666]]<|/det|> The total mark for this paper is 40. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 667, 729, 682]]<|/det|> The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 712, 907, 840]]<|/det|>

**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 594, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 720, 149]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a stand with two clamps attached.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 148, 737, 165]]<|/det|>
**Do not** change the positions of the clamps during the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 920, 212]]<|/det|>
Measure the distance \(x\) between the **centres** of the rods of the two clamps, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[278, 220, 715, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 443, 532, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<form>x = .................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 504, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with a length of resistance wire with crocodile clips attached to its ends.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 230, 134]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 116, 781, 135]]<|/det|>
Wrap the wire around the rods of the clamps, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 144, 776, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 454, 534, 473]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 485, 228, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 485, 777, 504]]<|/det|>
Connect the ohmmeter to the crocodile clips, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 516, 213, 534]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 516, 641, 534]]<|/det|>
Record the resistance \(R\) shown by the ohmmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 562, 917, 580]]<|/det|>
<form>R = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 818, 89]]<|/det|>
Five sections of wire are in contact with both rods, as shown in Fig. 1.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 97, 757, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 368, 534, 386]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 400, 191, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 400, 841, 418]]<|/det|>
Record the number \(n\) of sections of wire that are in contact with both rods.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 445, 917, 463]]<|/det|>
<form>n = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Change \(n\) by wrapping the wire around the rods a different number of times. Measure \(R\) and count \(n\). Continue until you have five sets of values of \(R\) and \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\left(n - \frac{1}{n}\right)\) to three significant figures in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 144, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 583, 175, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 579, 688, 603]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(R\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\left(n - \frac{1}{n}\right)\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 581, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 180, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 457, 631]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 612, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 644, 183, 663]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 644, 608, 663]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 861, 917, 880]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 892, 917, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 907, 920, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 99, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 613, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate an oscillating system.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 133, 144, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 180, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
You have been provided with two lengths of string and a wooden rod. Tie the strings to the rod at the positions of the lines, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 170, 761, 276]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 295, 532, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 326, 210, 344]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 326, 611, 344]]<|/det|>
Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 341, 759, 358]]<|/det|>
Both split corks should be at a height of \(55 \text{cm}\) above the bench.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[171, 365, 823, 686]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 696, 534, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 727, 212, 744]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 727, 920, 775]]<|/det|>
Adjust the strings in the split corks so that the lower end of the rod is \(30 \text{cm}\) above the bench and the upper end of the rod is \(38 \text{cm}\) above the bench, as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 789, 220, 807]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 789, 625, 807]]<|/det|>
Move the stands so that the strings are vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 820, 213, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 820, 808, 838]]<|/det|>
The horizontal distance between the strings is \(L\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 851, 423, 867]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 925, 920, 942]]<|/det|>
<form>L = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 72, 210, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 848, 87]]<|/det|>
Push the centre of the rod away from you. Release it and watch its motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 85, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
The rod will twist for a while and then swing for a very short time before twisting again and swinging again for a very short time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 212, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 752, 151]]<|/det|>
The time from when the rod swings to when it next swings is \(t_{\mathrm{s}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 165, 425, 183]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(t_{\mathrm{s}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 303, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
<form>\(t_{\mathrm{s}} =\) .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 335, 181, 353]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 814, 353]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(t_{\mathrm{s}}\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 488, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 72, 207, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 72, 892, 89]]<|/det|>
Leave the strings clamped in the split corks, but slide the string loops off the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 223, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
For the **longer** string, fill the loop with modelling clay to make a pendulum, as shown in Fig. 2.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 144, 697, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 428, 534, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 215, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 459, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
Push the modelling clay a short distance away from you. Take measurements to determine the period \(T_{1}\) of its oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 583, 920, 602]]<|/det|>
<form>T_1 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 615, 181, 633]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 615, 845, 633]]<|/det|>
Repeat **(b)**(i) for the **shorter** string to determine the period \(T_{2}\) of its oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 737, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
<form>T_2 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 770, 181, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 770, 354, 787]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(B\), where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 791, 559, 826]]<|/det|>
\[B = \frac{T_1T_2}{(T_1 - T_2)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 831, 400, 848]]<|/det|>
Give an appropriate unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 927, 920, 945]]<|/det|>
<form>B = .................................................... [1]

9702/32/M/J/22 **[Turn over**
